metadata.title: A multi-group SEIRA model for the spread of COVID-19 among heterogeneous populations Journal Pre-proof A multi-group SEIRA model for the spread of COVID-19 among heterogeneous populations A multi-group SEIRA model for the spread of COVID-19 among 1 heterogeneous populations

affiliation.laboratory: Laboratory for Rheology and Fluid Dynamics

abstract.text: • We derived a multi-group SEIRA model for representing the spreading dynamics of COVID-19 among populations formed by heterogeneous groups.
• Our model can represent heterogeneity arising from different sources, as geographical restrictions, behavioral or economic differences, age groups, and others.

• We propose our model to simulate scenarios for assessing and testing public health policies, such as total quarantine, restricted mobilization/interaction in cities, closed aerial/earthly/maritime routes, among others.
• We identified opportunities to extend our model to represent other scenarios, such as the temporal evolution of model parameters.
The outbreak and propagation of COVID-19 have posed a considerable challenge to modern society.

In particular, the different restrictive actions taken by governments to prevent the spread of the virus 12 have changed the way humans interact and conceive interaction. Due to geographical, behavioral, or 13 economic factors, different sub-groups among a population are more (or less) likely to interact, and thus 14 to spread/acquire the virus. In this work, we present a general multi-group SEIRA model for representing 15 the spread of COVID-19 among a heterogeneous population and test it in a numerical case of study. By 16 highlighting its applicability and the ease with which its general formulation can be adapted to particular 17 studies, we expect our model to lead us to a better understanding of the evolution of this pandemic and to 18 better public-health policies to control it.

Since the way individuals interact is one of the principal aspects of human society that has been affected 158 by this worldwide health emergency, we believe that including interactions in our models and analyses will 159 help us develop strategies that will lead us sooner to recover the richness it used to have.

body_text.text: Since the outbreak of novel SARS-CoV2 in late 2019, the world's reaction capacity has been challenged in 22 every possible way. From the first self-isolation measures to total lock-downs and quarantines for preventing 23 its spreading, the way humans interact has changed, and probably, for good. Joined efforts from the scientific 24 community have helped to design strategies for supporting public-health policies, and for providing a better 25 understanding of the current scenario. In particular, several mathematical models have been proposed in 26 recent weeks to fit public databases on the SARS-CoV2 outbreak and forecast its evolution. Despite their 27 particularities, most of them evolve from the well-known SIR model proposed by Kermack and McKendrick 28 (1927) . The basic idea behind this model, and its variants, is to divide a population in different compartments, 29 representing the S (susceptible), E (exposed), I (infected), A (asymptomatic), R (recovered), D (dead), Q (quarantined), among other fractions of it. Centering our analysis on the spread of COVID-19, and restricting 31 our search to those models recently proposed, we may find different combinations of the variables mentioned 32 above. 33 Even though research has been done on SIR and SIRD models for COVID-19, with different levels of Nevertheless, the different models listed above do not account for the several factors that could result in a 53 heterogeneous spread of the infection in the population. Barriers can be risen by the geo-spatial configuration 54 of a country and differential connectivity between its regions, or even by the way the different communities 55 or social classes interact in a city. Even though work has been done in multi-group SIR models (Hethcote In this work, we present a general multi-group SEIRA model for representing the spread of novel COVID-19 60 through populations with heterogeneous characteristics, such as a heavily centralized organization with poor 61 connections between the provinces, substantial social inequality among the population, or age/behavioral 62 groups. Due to the generality of our model, we can easily modify it to account for different particularities of 63 any population. In our model, we represent the interactions between the different groups by a non-necessarily 64 symmetrical matrix connecting the different sub-groups, accounting for the fraction that effectively interacts.

Particularities of novel COVID-19 were used to model the infection dynamics, so individuals could be infected 66 by foreigners in their region, or while they are visiting a different one. We apply our model in a case of study 67 for representing the dynamics between different behavioral groups, highlighting its applicability to the early 68 prediction of contingencies. Our model also accounts for Asymptomatic individuals A, but as we suppose them to represent a constant 88 α fraction of the total infected individuals, they are considered in the equation for I.

The general idea behind our model, and workflow of its network-scheme, is presented in Figure 1 . The 90 particular deduction and novelties involved in the SEIR equations are presented in the following section.

FIGREF1.text: presented a modified SEIR model, where variables S and E had an in-out function,39    accounting for quarantine, and E was considered to be infectious. Even though the model involved several40 variables, the parameter-fitting stage only considered an exponential approximation, leaving unclear how the 41 infection and recovery rates were decoupled. Another variant of SEIR models was presented by Yang and 42 Wang (2020), including an equation for the concentration of SARS-CoV2 in the environmental reservoir. 43 (Peng et al., 2020) present a sophisticated 7-compartment variant of SEIR models, where the extra variables 44 account for the quarantined Q, dead D, and insusceptible P fractions of the population. Moreover, their 45 model includes the temporal evolution of the rates of recovery and infection-driven death. Kucharski et al. 46 (2020) used a stochastic dynamic model to fit publicly available datasets of Wuhan to give better insights on the early dynamics of COVID-19, and therefore predict if newly introduced cases would generate outbreaks 48 in other areas. Pang (2020) present several public health recommendations, based on the modeling of the 49 effect of different regulations for preventing the spread of COVID-19 on a SEIRA model similar to the one 50 presented by Aguilar et al. (2020), highlighting the challenges that an epidemic of an aerial contagious virus 51 with asymptomatic patients pose.

FIGREF5.text: on which our model relies are the well-known mathematical and biological hypotheses71    for SEIR single and multi-group models(Hethcote and Thieme, 1985). Other suppositions, as listed below,72 are based on the state-of-the-art knowledge of COVID-19 and other population-balance considerations. There exists an incubation period for the virus, which average has been reported to range between 5.2 74 days (Li et al., 2020a; Lauer and Grantz, 2020) and 6.4 days (Backer et al., 2020). This fact justifies 75 the existence of a compartment E (exposed). The asymptomatic fraction of a given population, which varies from 29% (Li et al., 2020b), going through 77 50% (Mizumoto et al., 2020) and rising between 50 and 75% (Day, 2020), will be considered constant α. 78 This hypothesis makes sense if the size of the population and its immunological characteristics are 79 homogeneous. The only possible interaction among different classes is infection. Recoveries and deaths are supposed 81 to occur in the group where they belong. Asymptomatic patients are ξ times more likely to transmit the infection successfully to a healthy 83 patient. Even though the viral load of asymptomatic individuals is in the same order of magnitude 84 than in symptomatic patients (Zou et al., 2020), our supposition relies on a social-interaction basis.85Symptomatic patients are easily avoided, quarantined, or likely to choose self-isolation, which is not 86 the case of asymptomatic individuals.

FIGREF7.text: Our approach proposes the partition of a heterogeneous population into several (as-many-as-required) sub-populations, where the hypotheses for SEIR models are satisfied. The different populations share common characteristics, as a geographical zone (this scheme), but not restricted only to that interpretation. This same reasoning (and model) can be applied to different behavioral groups, social classes, and age groups, through an appropriate interpretation for the interaction function.3. Fractions of C 125 are likely to provide services in zones A and B, and therefore interact with their population. Zone B acts as 126 the center of the city, where people meet for office work. FIGREF14.text: of COVID-19 in the SARS-CoV2 outbreak through populations with heterogeneous characteristics, which 146 may be given by geographical particularities of the territory, or marked behavioral differences among social 147 classes in a city, country or region. Because of its generality, this model can represent several mechanisms of 148 interaction between different sub-populations and may lead to a better understanding of the evolution of this 149 pandemic, and thus to better public-health policies. Numeric simulations of cases 1-4, with outbreak parameters β = 0.11, γ = 0.034, θ = 0.001, ξ = 2, α = 0.3, n = 10 5 [2.5 5 6], β q = 0.044, I A (t = 0) = 10. Note that this simulation does not consider the saturation of the local health-system, a parameter that drastically increases the mortality rate of this virus when surpassed.The general structure of the model presented on this work can be easily modified to account for different151 particularities of given populations or to support policy makers to take public health decisions with greater 152 effectiveness. For instance, the effect of behavioral changes in the population affecting beta, the saturation of 153 the public health system, and the transient dynamics of the fluxes or interactions between sub-populations can 154 be easily implemented in the model by setting the correct functional form in the parameters. As introducing 155 such dynamics would imply adding more parameters, we suggest doing so only if there is enough data to fit gratefully acknowledge support from the Chilean National Agency for Research and develop-169 ment through ANID PIA Grant AFB180004, and the Centre for Biotechnology and Bioengineering -CeBiB 170 (PIA project FB0001, Conicyt, Chile).
